discussion.content:
Admin please put the answer in the solution tab not at the end of question D
Thank you.

questions.question_text: As part of an organization's compliance program, administrators must complete a hardening checklist and note any potential improvements. The process of noting improvements in the checklist is MOST likely driven by:

choices.A: the collection of data as part of the continuous monitoring program.
choices.D: changes in operating systems or industry trends.
choices.C: the organization's software development life cycle.
choices.B: adherence to policies associated with incident response.

questions.question_text:
A security engineer has been hired to design a device that will enable the exfiltration of data from within a well-defended network perimeter during an authorized test. The device must bypass all firewalls and NIDS in place, as well as allow for the upload of commands from a centralized command and control server . The total cost of the device must be kept to a minimum in case the device is discovered during an assessment.
Which of the following tools should the engineer load onto the device being designed?

discussion.content:
answer D. Reverse shell endpoint listener 
I've actually used this technique in the past. Have the device ssh out, using key auth and reverse tunnel, to an outside target. Works nearly as well as a VPN if set up correctly.
Answer D. The keywords here are:must bypass all firewalls and NIDS in place...

comments.content: I am not convinced a reverse listener would bypass all firewalls and NIDS. I think a reverse listener has to focus on certain ports, if those ports are blocked by the firewall, or if NIDS detects traffic on those ports, then the endpoint listener will not work.

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. Automatic MITM proxy ?
"mitmproxy is your swiss-army knife for debugging, testing, privacy measurements, and penetration testing. It can be used to intercept, inspect, modify and replay web traffic such as HTTP/1, HTTP/2, WebSockets, or any other SSL/TLS-protected protocols. You can prettify and decode a variety of message types ranging from HTML to Protobuf, intercept specific messages on-the-fly, modify them before they reach their destination, and replay them to a client or server later on. "
https://mitmproxy.org/
This wouldn’t work. A listener would mean that we would have to make it through the firewall with the attack box. Maybe the tcp beacon?

choices.A: Custom firmware with rotating key generation

comments.content: Neo nailed it here. The key word is "sensitive site"

discussion.content: A security consultant is improving the physical security of a sensitive site and takes pictures of the unbranded building to include in the report. The main issue here is the GEOTAGGING INFO of SENSITIVE SITE. SO C in this context. C.

Admin please put the answer in the solution tab not at the end of question D
Thank you.
Maybe A. Is not encrypted. Confidentiality.

Maybe: B. MicroSD contains a mixture of personal and work data ?
On the phone: "Consultancy HR Manual.doc" 
HR? As in human resources? That could have all kinds of data about corporate employees.

Errors aside, the answer is A. There's nothing I can see to say that the address listed is geotag information, and there are TAX documents on this unencrypted drive (which have a buttload of personal data AND your address). if there were 2 options it would be A/C, but the BIGGEST problem is A, all the personal info on the unencrypted drive.

comments.content:
According to Question #366 Geotag information does not look like an address, it looks like this:
JFIF
40 42.8562N
74 0.3582W
Good catch on the tax info.

discussion.content: They need to work on their grammar. It is not in, it is supposed to be is after MicroSD in choice A and C.

questions.question_text:
A security consultant is improving the physical security of a sensitive site and takes pictures of the unbranded building to include in the report. Two weeks later, the security consultant misplaces the phone, which only has one hour of charge left on it. The person who finds the phone removes the MicroSD card in an attempt to discover the owner to return it.
The person extracts the following data from the phone and EXIF data from some files:

DCIM Images folder -

Audio books folder -

Torrentz -

My TAX.xls -

Consultancy HR Manual.doc -

Camera: SM-G950F -

Exposure time: 1/60s -

Location: 3500 Lacey Road USA -
Which of the following BEST describes the security problem?

choices.A: MicroSD in not encrypted and also contains personal data.
choices.D: MicroSD contains pirated software and is not encrypted.
choices.C: MicroSD in not encrypted and contains geotagging information.
choices.B: MicroSD contains a mixture of personal and work data.

questions.question_text:
An engineer needs to provide access to company resources for several offshore contractors. The contractors require:
✑ Access to a number of applications, including internal websites
✑ Access to database data and the ability to manipulate it
✑ The ability to log into Linux and Windows servers remotely
Which of the following remote access technologies are the BEST choices to provide all of this access securely? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
D. VDI - For remote access
E. VPN - For secure access

Maybe: C. VLAN ?
Need "The ability to log into Linux and Windows servers remotely" I am not sure that is common with a VDI.
VLAN: logical group of workstations, servers and network devices that appear to be on the same LAN despite their geographical distribution

Answer is B: PaaS
In Platform-aaS, the host (e.g. AWS, Azure) maintains the infrastructure and the Operating system and the software to support the OS and installed components (like a DB). The organization buying the service focuses on their application that will run on this platform.

IaaS requires you to install and support the OS and any related applications.

comments.content: The question mentions "underlying server applications" so, that may mean PaaS.

discussion.content: Answer B: IaaS is really limited to storage, networking and compute. PaaS would add some functionality such as operating systems, some software and other middle-ware. In this case, the team is doing application development, they will not want to deal with many of the "sys admin" tasks that could be performed by the PaaS. See: https://www.bmc.com/blogs/saas-vs-paas-vs-iaas-whats-the-difference-and-how-to-choose/

Agree with C, Iaas.
PaaS would include things like using a cloud-managed database or cloud-hosted code execution (like aws Lambda). Since they are, presumably, building out an entire application stack on someone else's infrastructure, this would be an IaaS solution.

Maybe: C. IaaS?
The answer seems to be in the question: "...host them in a vendor's cloud-based infrastructure." Note: "infrastructure." As in: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS).

comments.content: The answer lies in this sentence: "... but will not manage the underlying server applications"

questions.question_text: A project manager is working with a team that is tasked to develop software applications in a structured environment and host them in a vendor's cloud-based infrastructure. The organization will maintain responsibility for the software but will not manage the underlying server applications. Which of the following does the organization plan to leverage?
